question: Question_01_(c)
sols:
To evaluate this integral, we are going to use substitution, but first
we rearrange the integral a little bit,

\begin{align*}
\int\cos^{3}x\sin^{4}x\,dx &= \int (\cos^{3}x)(\sin^{4}x)dx
\\ &=\int (\cos^{2}x)(\sin^{4}x)(\cos x \,dx)
\end{align*} Let

\[u = \sin(x) \quad \Rightarrow \quad du = \cos x\,dx\] Also, we use the
trig. identity,

\[\cos^{2}x + \sin^{2}x = 1\quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \cos^{2}x= 1 - \sin^{2}x.\]
giving us,

\begin{align*}
\int (\cos^{2}x)(\sin^{4}x)(\cos x \,dx) &= \int (1 - \sin^{2}x)(\sin^{4}x)(\cos x\,dx)
\\ &=\int (1-u^{2})(u^{4})(du)
\\ &=\int (u^{4}-u^{6})\,du
\\ &=\frac{u^{5}}{5}-\frac{u^{7}}{7} + C
\\ {\color{blue}\int\cos^{3}x\sin^{4}x\,dx }&\,{\color{blue}=\frac{\sin^{5}x}{5}-\frac{\sin^{7}x}{7} + C}\end{align*}
